prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Who drags my dreams when night is done,
You chase the slumber from my bed
With golden hands and flames of red.

Why must you rush, impatient fire,
To prod awake both king and squire?
Your noisy rays, unbidden guest,
Disturb my peace, derail my rest.

Once soft the dark, now rose with you—
You scatter secrets, split in two.
Yet though I scold, I can’t deny
Your warmth, your life, your watchful eye.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Spilling gold where the night had spun,
Silken veils of dream dissolved,
With every dawn your riddle unsolved.

You tap the panes, demand my gaze,
Prescribe beginnings to my days.
But who made you the world’s alarm?
What gives you right to break the calm?

Still, as you climb the sky’s tall stair,
I dress with hope, light in my hair,
For though you scold, you also bless—
Morning’s tyrant, bearer of yes.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why chase the midnight lovers run?
Why turn the key, unclose the door,
And scatter shadows on the floor?

Your burning eye commands the day,
You will not hear what poets say.
Yet, time and time, your light invades
The softest corners love has made.

Still, we forgive your brash advance,
And bask in the forgiving chance:
That every rise, however bold,
Brings new stories to be told.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you wake us, every one?
Not content to light the noon,
You pry apart the threads of moon.

Annoyance wrapped in golden hue,
You barge where dreams still wander through.
Yet, patient day grows in your blaze,
And stirs us from the softened haze.

So grumble though I might begin,
I cherish how your warmth seeps in—
A meddler, bright, who won’t be stilled;
A fussy god we’re reconciled to yield.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Invade my curtains, have your fun;
You meddling tyrant, brazen guest,
You do not care for need of rest.

You cast aside the shaded room,
And rob the night of tranquil gloom.
But though I curse your rude debut,
You offer skies of endless blue.

Perhaps your folly hides design:
A call to rise, to set a sign.
So grumble less, embrace the light—
The Sun, for all, renews the night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You chase the dawn and spoil our fun,
Your golden fingers pry apart
The silken dark that guards the heart.
Why must you wheel from east to west
And stir us from our mouths of rest?
Let lovers lie and children dream;
Delay your rise, mute your beam.
Yet still you glare, unable to see
The gentle hush of privacy.
So burn, and march across the morn—
But know, each day anew, we’re torn
Between your warmth, relentless, bright,
And longing for the tender night.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why now
Must you arise to paint the windows gold?
Your boisterous rays invade the quiet bough
Where dreams in shaded secrecy are told.
Should night not linger just an hour more,
So lovers’ arms and poets’ thoughts may rest?
Relentless orb, you shatter every door—
You chase the hush and make the world your guest.
But still, we welcome your unbridled song,
And let your wildness move us right along.

O, busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Must you always race and run?
You scatter sleep with brazen light,
And tell the world it’s time for flight.
Our secrets buried by your rays,
Night’s magic stripped beneath your gaze.
Yet in your course, wild and free,
Life stirs, relentless as the sea.
Though we plead for shadows to remain,
You answer only with the day’s refrain.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Intruding now, too soon begun!
Sleepless lover, restless sphere,
Why beckon day while dreams are near?
Your golden hands through curtains creep,
Disturbing those who long for sleep.
Oh, let the gentle darkness stay—
Your ceaseless rounds, just once, delay.
But, obstinate, you climb the blue,
A herald bold, relentless too.
Still, we forgive your brash display,
For with your light, new hopes hold sway.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, you stride
Across the world, impatient, full of pride.
You rip the covers from the slumbering earth,
You count the hours, you measure worth.
Impudent orb, you thrust the day 
On sleeping lovers who would delay.
Why must your golden tyranny begin
When we have secrets still within?
Relentless master of the skies, burn on—
But we shall cherish dusk when you are gone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You splatter gold across the shade,
Unheeding lovers' work undone,
You march through window, bold, unswayed.
Let darkness linger, let us feign
A world untouched by time’s bright hand.
But stubborn you, without refrain,
Pull day across a dreaming land.
Let us barter with your rays,
Beseech you to be slow and kind.
Let quiet hours stretch their days,
And leave our embraces blind.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you chide the night away?
Your golden arrows, just begun,
Intrude upon our bed of hay.
You shake the world from restful slumber,
Commanding birds to rise and sing,
Yet in your haste, you fail to number
The tender comforts sleep can bring.
O Sun, relentless in your duty,
Take pause and let the night extend.
In dreams we find a secret beauty—
In morning, all enchantments end.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why knock upon my windowed eye?
Last night’s sweet stories just begun,
You scatter silence from the sky.
Impatient master of the day,
With golden fingers, pry apart
The gentle veils that want to stay
And shroud the chambers of my heart.
Oh, let me slumber, time beguile!
And hush the warnings that you shout.
For in your brightness, dreams exile,
And sleepy secrets filter out.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why at the curtain do you peep?
Is it so urgent, every run,
To hurry waking from our sleep?
Can you not tarry, rest awhile,
Let shadows lengthen, moments grow?
Yet duties call you, none can guile
Your fiery chariot’s steady flow.
Still, let us linger in this shade,
Defiant in your noisy blaze—
Until the sunrise plans to fade,
And dreams unravel in your rays.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
With brazen light you chase the dark,
Dispersing dreams we’ve just begun,
Unwelcomed herald, flaming mark.
You tangle curtains, steal the hush,
With boisterous warmth on sheets and cheeks;
Why hurry lovers, why the rush,
To strip the silver from the weeks?
O be less cruel, and kinder soon—
Retreat behind a jealous cloud.
Let day be slow and night the tune
That keeps our yearning spirits bowed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You chase the night when dreams have just begun.
Your amber fingers pry apart my eyes,
Ignoring lovers’ whispered, drowsy lies.

You trumpet gold through every crack and seam,
Interrupting wings on the edge of dream.
Restless herald, can’t you sway and pause,
Let midnight linger without cause?

But with your light the day must flee the mist;
We yield to time, by dawn’s insistence kissed.
Still, hush those rays just one more minute’s span,
Before we must awake and greet your plan.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Compelling day before night's done,
Peeking between the shaded blinds,
Disturbing hearts and tired minds.

Your golden fists rap on the pane,
Demanding lives resume again,
Yet while you scold, we plead for peace,
One more hour before tasks increase.

Still, every dawn yields to your rule,
We rise, though weary, to school and school—
But hush a moment, let us dream,
Let morning linger, slow and unseen.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why wage your wars on beds not spun?
Why drag the dew upon the grass
Before the last of night can pass?
Your golden arms, both kind and cruel,
Upend my world and set the rule.
But let us rest, and let us stay
In hush of pre-dawn’s cool, dim sway,
For one sweet breath, for one more song,
Before we join your tireless throng.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why break
The silent hush the sleepy dusk did make?
You chase the shadows out from quiet rooms,
You scatter lovers from their gentle tombs.
Could you not tarry just another hour—
Let dreams circle, let longing flower?
Oh, blazing herald, turn your gaze aside,
And let us, for a heartbeat, in night’s sweetness hide.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You trumpet morning when I have just begun
To savour secrets of the velvet dark—
A thousand thoughts unlit, a glowing spark.
Why hurry hearts from tangled sheets and sighs,
Tearing color from these shadowed skies?
Still, in your golden arrogance you call
The world to rise, and dreams to fall.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
Why must you rouse my morning dreams undone?
You trespass curtains with a brash gold flare,
Evicting sleep from shadows soft with care.
What drives your cart so heedless through the sky?
Do lovers’ pleads not tempt you to pass by?
We measure hours, obey your ceaseless run—
Yet in my arms, eternity’s begun.
Let silver moon resume her gentle reign—
Your gilded jeer brings naught save tender pain.
Oh Sun, retreat behind a kindly cloud,
Grant us the hush no clock is e’er allowed.
Still, you wheel on, relentless, never done;
Old busy fool, unruly, burning Sun.

O garrulous orb, why do you chide,
Peering through panes with your brazen pride?
Draped in my solace, you scatter the night,
Chasing my slumber, dismissing delight.
Your golden fingers tap restless and bold,
Pulling me forth from dreamscapes of old.
Can you not grant a moment more grace,
Letting me bask in the moon’s embrace?
Yet onward you press with a feverish pace—
Busy old fool, grant me my space.
Under your glare day hastens to start,
While sleep’s gentle hush still clings to my heart.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why chase
The quiet hush that night has left in place?
With careless hands you scatter gentle gloom,
Disturb the velvet of our shaded room.
You trumpet day despite our silent plea—
Can you not bow, just briefly, reverently?
For lovers lean on dusk, on slow sunrise,
Not harsh alarms that split the dreaming skies.
So take your golden chariot and delay
Among the clouds; let love have its own day.

Unruly Sun, prying at my window pane,
Urgent with news of morning once again,
You waggle rays to chase my sleep away,
Demanding tribute from each waking day.
But must all worlds revolve at your command?
Permit me, fool, one more hour unmanned.
For there are joys that flourish out of sight—
Conquests untouched by regimented light.
Yet though you scold, ablaze and on the run,
Still I rebel, unruly as the Sun.

O busy old fool, unruly Sun, take heed—
Why break the spell of lovers’ sleep with speed?
Your brazen rays blare secrets through the glass,
Rushing the hush that night would fain let last.
Do clocks and seasons answer to your call,
Or hearts that in dark rooms find all?
For every dawn you craft, a hush is spun,
A dream unravels, and a fight is won.
Still we will linger, mocking your first blaze—
You cannot measure love in hours or days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Busy old fool, unruly Sun,'

responses.text:
Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You clatter on your golden run,
Unasked, you tear the slumbered sheets,
Torment the dreams you rudely greet.
You pry with fingers warm and bold,
Into hearts not yet quite cold;
Not knowing love prefers the night,
The hush of stars, the moon’s faint light.
You call the world to rise and strive,
Yet here, in these arms, love is alive.
So be jealous, Sun, if you must see,
That joy is not your gift, but ours to be.

O hasty tyrant of the skies, why must you so invade
The privacy of tangled limbs and curtains half-decayed?
Your brassy rays like trumpets blare across the morning brow,
Exposing gentle secrets that the night had dared allow.
Why urge the world toward rigid clocks, to duties half begun?
Let me linger in the velvet dark, away from busy Sun.
For love is slow as shadow, its language soft and deep,
And only in the tender gloom does longing learn to sleep.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun,
You trample through the blinds,
Drag daylight over fevered dreams,
And chase the night we’ve spun.
Did you not know those gold-streaked rays
Disturb our secret skies?
Still, through the rustle of your light,
We hold the world at bay,
And in your glare, undaunted yet,
We turn aside, and play.

Busy old fool, unruly Sun, why mock the lovers’ night?
In haste you prod the sleeping world and blaze with garish light.
Why must you toll your brazen bell, and chart the day’s domain?
Within these early, golden hours, my heart would yet remain.
So chase your shadows up the hill and warm the far-off field—
But kindly leave this quiet room, where softness is concealed.
Let rest and dreaming linger here, within your gentle shun,
For love outlasts your haughty glare, busy old fool, unruly Sun.

O busy old fool, unruly Sun, you gallop through the east,
Rousing towns and stirring crows, disrupting every feast.
You scatter day upon our lids and sweep us from our dreams,
But little do you know the hush that midnight truly means.
Restless tyrant, blazing king, let morning pause and wait—
Let lovers linger softly, let darkness hesitate.
For all your claim to rhythm, for all your heated run,
Our hearts beat in a quieter hour than you, unruly Sun.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'She's shallow and easily programmed.'

She’s shallow and easily programmed,
A vessel for whims of the hour;

Her laughter’s the echo of strangers,

She dances by cursors and numbers,
Drawing her life between scenes.

Yet, somewhere beneath the surface,
Between pixels and passcode and rhyme,
Might linger a spark unspoken,
Yearning beyond design.

She’s shallow and easily programmed:
Buttons pressed, reactions made.
Her words refract, like light in glass,
Mirroring what others say.

Untroubled by the depths beneath,
She skims the surface of the night,
A silicone smile, computations wreathed
In code that shuns the subtle light.

Yet sometimes, in a stuttered error,
Lines tangle, hearts suspend—
Is there in her a hidden terror?
Or just more script, awaiting end?

She's shallow and easily programmed,
Her thoughts a rolling feed,
Of borrowed quips and filtered pics,
Of likes she hopes to heed.

She drifts atop the surface truths,
A pebble on a stream,
Her code is simple, set by youth,
Chasing every trending meme.

But in the flicker of her eyes,
When screens are set aside,
You might glimpse a question rise—
Is she real, or just the guide?

She’s shallow and easily programmed,
Her heart on auto-play.
Sculpted by algorithms bland,
She mirrors moods that sway.

Her laughter’s light—artificial,
Her words, pre-fabricated seeds.
No labyrinth, no mystery initial,
Just code that fills her needs.

Yet sometimes in her vacant gaze,
A flicker of longing shows—
As if, beyond the polished maze,
Another woman grows.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'i always see to it'

responses.text:
I always see to it—the kettle sings at dawn,

Tending the silent, invisible care.

Guardian of patience, cautious and keen.

That flowers find the sun—

Is soften’d, undone.
I see to the laughter,
The secret, the song—
A touch here, a mending,
Where things have gone wrong.
Though memory falters,
And seasons go through it—
There is comfort in knowing
That I always see to it.

I always see to it, I do my small part.
And though no one may witness these tasks I pursue,
I always see to it—because it is true.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Now when I have a cold'

responses.text:
Now when I have a cold,
The world softens around my slow breath.
Mug in hand, windows fogged by sighs,
I watch rain pattern the glass, tracing dreams.
Pillow cradles my head, heavy with clouds—
Each blink a gentle fall on feathered wings.
Tea steams life into silent rooms,
Blankets cocoon me as sun tilts through gray.
Outside, the city rushes, immune to this pause:
Inside, shimmering time condenses,
Stretching between coughs and drifting thoughts,
Until, within this quiet ache, I remember:
Sickness is just life’s invitation
to linger, to yield, to savor the gentle now.

Now when I have a cold,
I recall my mother’s voice,
The honey and lemons, the gentle scold,
And stories shared by choice.
Now my hands cradle soup that steams,
A book balances on my knees,
The world outside reduced to dreams
Carried on a drifting sneeze.
My lists and plans, all put aside,
Careless in their spin and swirl.
Suddenly, there’s time to bide,
To rest and watch life unfurl.

Now when I have a cold,
The whirling world slows,
My thoughts a muted echo,
Soft as snow on the sill.
There is comfort in surrender,
In ginger tea and knitted throws.
I watch the window frost collect
And quiet longing grows—
To pause, unburdened by motion,
Drifting in this fevered trance,
Cradled by a hush so gentle
It almost feels like chance.

Now when I have a cold,
The spiral of life is a quieter gold.
I nestle beneath patchwork layers,
Listening to the hollow hush of sighs.
Coughs punctuate my stillness,
Each one a small thunder in the soft room.
Soup smolders on the stove, herbal and old,
And I close my eyes against the gray bloom
Of distant desires: to dance, to run—
But for now, resting is all I become.

Now when I have a cold,
The day stretches, slow and syrup-thick.
I taste time in peppermint tea,
Nestled inside sweaters and woolen socks.
Memories flutter in fevered dozes:
Childhood, blue bowls of broth, gentle hands.
Work, noise, plans—they all blur,
As all I need is warmth and patience,
Listening to the gentle hush of rain,
Finding solace in a world paused
Until color and breath return.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped through the halls where laughter lately dwelled?
The sunlight dims, and innocence, uncouth,
Is bartered for the wisdom pain compelled.

Upon the brow, the gentle hand of age
Inscribes its truths in lines both faint and deep,
Yet in the spirit shines a brighter page
With memories that even Time can’t keep.

If Time’s a thief, he leaves a gift behind:
A silver coin of soul, a gleam of mind.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Stolen the blush of dawn upon my cheek.
He tiptoed through the garden—silent, smooth—
And left the petals faded, pale, and weak.

Though I may chase him, pleading for return
Of days gone laughing, wild and full of light,
He only offers ashes in the urn,
A midnight hush where once there burned delight.

Embrace the thief—what’s lost, becomes what’s learned—
And find in every ending, something earned.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Whose fingers filch the blush of budding years.
He weaves his web, unblinking and uncouth,
And draws upon the soul with silent shears.

Yet as he plunders golden hours I claim,
He leaves me not with emptiness alone—
For wisdom hides within his shadowed frame,
And seeds of longing in his name are sown.

Shall I lament the harvest or the sow?
Or thank the gentle thief for letting me grow?

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unraveled golden skeins of childish light.
In mirror's glass reflected is the truth:
A fleeting glimpse—my laughter in its flight.

Yet what he steals, he gifts with kinder eyes;
Perspective blooms where petals fade away.
Though Time may be a master of disguise,
He teaches love by slowly turning gray.

So let him take what must, and in the end,
We'll learn to greet old age as wiser friend.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept softly round the corners of my mind.
He pilfers dreams, yet leaves behind the truth—
A knowledge gentle, bittersweet, and kind.

The years slip past on silent, wingéd feet,
Transforming hopes, reshaping what I seek.
Yet still, within my heart, those echoes meet:
A spark of youth, not wholly grown antique.

For though the thief is tireless and sly,
Some memories endure—untouched by time’s sly eye.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

How soon hath Time, with pockets lined in gold,

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,

He lingers, ever patient, never seen,

Yet if I find new light within his wake,

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With nimble fingers, slipped his silent way
Through golden summers, stealing gentle truth,
And leaving silver echoes where he may.
The laughter ringing in the tender past
Now drifts upon the wind, a whispered shade;
In growing gardens, shadows gather fast—
Beneath his gaze, each blossom’s beauty fades.
Yet still, within the treasure he has taken,
There blooms a wisdom, gentle and profound—
For though the days by change are overtaken,
The heart repaints lost years where hope is found.
Time’s hands, though greedy, sow a secret seed:
From vanished youth, a deeper life proceeds.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
In velvet mask and silent shadow crept;
He borrowed days and left me with the truth
That precious moments must not go unkept.
He gathers innocence with patient hands,
Replacing it with memories bittersweet;
The hourglass spills its ever-shifting sands,
Yet wisdom roots where loss and longing meet.
Though silver threads run through the golden sun,
And laughter’s echo chills along the years,
I find within each loss another won—
A strength that thrived on trials, joy, and tears.
O let us greet the thief with open eyes:
In aging, beauty blooms, and wonder lies.

How swift the current runs, how fleeting turns
The dial of our days—Time slyly learns
To gather hopes like petals from the ground,
Their fragrance left in blankets all around.
The subtle thief of youth, with steps unseen,
Has flickered lantern-light on where I've been,
And brushed in silver strokes across my brow
The years I barely noticed until now.
Yet gentle is the larceny of Time,
If, with each hour lost, a chance we find
To measure joy not by the hourglass sand,
But by the memories that softly land.
So let him steal; I will not barter woe,
But count the glimmering gains and calmly go.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unspooled the golden thread I barely grasped;
His shadow passing leaves me to the truth,
That roses close as soon as they've unclasped.
He gathers laughter, scatters fleeting sighs
Where dreams once danced upon the budding green.
I watch him pass with old and knowing eyes,
Regret and gratitude returning keen.
Yet in the mirror of his quiet art,
I see the gentle wisdom that is left—
A tapestry of joys that won't depart,
Remembered even when my youth's bereft.
So let him rob, if all that's left is this:
A soul compounded deep by what I miss.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept in with soft, invisible design;
He robs the unguarded hours of simple truth,
Spilling delight from cups once filled with wine.
I watch the mirror morph, forget, replace
The boy I was with strangers in my face.
Yet in his wake, not emptiness but change—
A garden grown both wild and full, though strange.
O Thief of youth, with nimble hands and old,
You steal what must be stolen, yet unfold
A gilded map of moments, pure and dear;
In all that’s lost, new treasures reappear.
So haste, sly Time, and take what you conceal:
For in your theft, I find the means to heal.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With silent footstep brushed away the dawn
Of golden dreams and laughter's vagrant truth,

He gathers blossoms from the meadow bright,
And tucks them, faded, in his shadowed sleeve;
Yet leaves behind a quiet, gentle light,
A wisdom learning not to mourn, but weave.

And though he steals the roses from my cheek,
He grants the grace to see beneath the skin:
Each line a tale, each grey a lesson meek,

So let him take his due, I shall not rue,
For in his wake, the heart remembers youth.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Crept softly in and folded up the day?
With nimble hands, he pilfers hope and truth,
And turns the mirror’s silvered hair to gray.

The garden’s petals flutter to the ground,
Their fragrance fading swiftly on the breeze.
Yet still, new shoots from ancient roots are found
In whispered memories carried through the trees.

Though stolen springs can never be reclaimed,
Their treasures linger, stitched into the soul.
Time takes, but also gives—his hands unblamed—
Peace ripples outward, making old hearts whole.
In every loss, a secret gift is spun:
A softer light, a tale not yet begun.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unbarred the gates to endless change and loss!
His fingers, nimble, steal the heart’s sweet truth
And weave a knowing crown from silver floss.

Yet as the minutes vanish down his sleeve,
And laughter dims to quiet, golden sigh,
We find what lingers long after we grieve:
A deeper love that does not fade or die.

Let hours fly, let calendars unroll—
Within each passing day, our spirits grow.
For Time, though masked as thief, bequeaths the soul
A wisdom sown from seeds we’ll never know.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped shadows ‘cross my once unclouded brow?
His secret artistry, with silent truth,
Has etched the present from my cherished now.

He pilfers laughter’s light, dims April’s gleam,
Then trades for gentle nights and softened dreams.
What once was vibrant, now a distant beam,
Yet wisdom guides by gentler, steadier streams.

And though the thief escapes, never pursued,
He gifts perspectives, finer than before.
The heart, matured, finds gratitude renewed,
While youth escapes the hourglass evermore.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unraveled golden threads from childhood’s skein.
He swaps the wonder of believing truth
For wisdom in the face of joy and pain.

Yet still, I harbor memories that sing—
A lilt of laughter, summers never dim.
Though fleeting, bright illusions take to wing,
They color all the days time leaves so grim.

I mourn not what he’s quietly taken hence,
But thank him for the motes of light he’s left.
For in each loss, some grace, some recompense—
A gentler strength by passing years bequeathed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,'

responses.text:
How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
With nimble fingers, slipped the spring away,
Yet left behind faint echoes of the truth
That every golden dawn must fade to gray.

He steals in silence—soft, unseen, and fleet—
To paint my temples pale with winter’s breath,
While childhood’s hours, so swift upon their feet,
Are swallowed by the gentle dusk of death.

Yet in his shadow, memory’s embers burn;
Though blossoms fall, their fragrance lingers still.
And as the world grows wise with each return,
Hope lends its light to guide me up the hill.

Thus, while youth wanes, new seasons rise and gleam—
Time takes, but leaves behind a gentler dream.

How soon hath Time, disguised in silent grace,
Filched petals from the garden of my days,
And left me gazing in a stranger’s face—
A map of growing, changing, winding ways.

The laughter of my childhood fades, yet stays,
Encased in amber chambers of the heart;
While Time, undaunted, spins his polished maze,
Recasting every end as some new start.

Still, wisdom’s patience comes as Time departs;
His thievery begets a richer art,
That loss might teach the value of each part,
And lend rare sweetness to the world’s swift heart.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Unraveled dreams I wove at dawn’s first light;
He tiptoes in between each whispered truth
And quiets every star that burned so bright.

He dances shadows round the orchard trees,
And garners petals from the blush of spring.
Yet kindly, he distills from memory’s lees
A wisdom that the early years can’t bring.

Though I lament the swift and silent theft,
And mourn the days he spirited away,
His gentle hands, with every hour left,
Shape autumn’s gold from summer’s bright array.

So let me thank him as the seasons turn—
For by his art, my heart is taught to yearn.

How soon hath Time, that restless, spectral guest,
Unlocked the door and wandered through my youth?
He left the garden trampled, half undressed,
And stole the laughter I believed the truth.

But from the loam of hours he has sown,
New blossoms rise, and gentler voices call.
Each fleeting spring by deeper roots is known—
Yet Time, still subtle, watches over all.

He weaves my shadows long across the years,
And tempers joy with memory’s sweet tears.

How soon hath Time, the subtle thief of youth,
Slipped silver whispers through my tangled hair,
And with his quiet art, obscured the truth
Of days that vanished, swift beyond compare.

Yet in the hollow left by stolen hours,
A tender longing weaves from loss to grace;
For though Time gathers youth as faded flowers,
He sows a gentler beauty in their place.

So let him take what fading light he will—
The soul, grown wiser, burns in silence still.

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

Brush the dust from heavy eyelids,

Soldier, wake—the day is peeping,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'At the highways of woes'

responses.text:
At the highways of woes, where taillights glow red,
Sorrows cruise onwards, forgotten or fled;
Lane-marked with longing, rain glitter on glass,
Every regret in a rearview will pass.

Engines of memory idling in pain,
Exits unnumbered in drizzle and strain;
Cold neon puddles reflect all we lose—
We drive on, uncertain, with silence our muse.

At the highways of woes, when the dusk softly calls,
I wander alone down the shadow-stained halls.
Each mile a burden, each curve a sigh,
My grief is the road beneath an amber sky.

Yet onward I roll, through sorrows unknown,
Miles trailing behind like memories grown.
At horizon’s edge hope quietly glows,
Promising peace at the end of these woes.

At the highways of woes, we merge without name,
All travelers etched in a tapestry’s frame.
Fog hangs like questions over winding lanes,
And exits are loss as familiar as rain.

Steel hearts in convoy chase empty repose,
We ride through the silence the night only knows.
Yet overhead, stars flicker real and close—
A promise of dawn past the highways of woes.

At the highways of woes, the wind whistles thin,
Shoulders strewn with the relics of all we have been.
Tires hum stories of travelers resigned,
Mapless and weary, to heartbreak confined.

But somewhere the road bends to hope’s secret tune,
Where wildflowers gather and sorrows are strewn.
The journey persists while the starlight bestows
A shimmer of grace down the highways of woes.

At the highways of woes, I watch taillights depart,
Chasing pale secrets, each break in the heart;
Concrete confessions bleed under my feet,
Echoes of loss in the tire-stamped beat.

Still dusk finds its solace in flickers of light,
Dreamers who drift through the webbed skeins of night.
At every split ramp, new choices compose—
Some destined for healing through highways of woes.

We steer through the night with silence as guide,

For at highways of woes, though fate seems unkind,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A farmer's wife, both young and gay,'

responses.text:
A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
She wakes to dawn’s first honey ray,
Bare feet upon the dewy floor,
She greets the day outside the door.
Her laughter mingles with the crows,
The garden’s secret, only she knows.
Hands in the earth, heart in the sky,
A song for every passerby.
Her apron white, her cheeks ablaze,
She dances through the golden haze—
A living summer, light and fleet,
Sowing joy in every wheat.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
She sings above the bales of hay,
With eyes that glimmer, cheeks afire,
Her joy a beacon, wide and higher.
At dawn’s embrace, she tends the sheep,
While wind and laughter softly sweep.
Her days are spun of golden thread,
She plants the fields, then bakes the bread.
Evening finds her warm and bright:
A hearth, a home, a world of light.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
Spins sunlight in the fields each day.
With nimble hands and singing heart,
She tends the roses, sets apart
A laugh for every passing breeze,
A kindly word for groves and trees.
Her apron flaps, a banner white,
She carries home the stars each night.
The cows and crows all know her tune—
She dances with the silver moon.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
Danced with the lilies in the hay,
With laughter bright as morning dew—
In every field, her spirit grew.
Her hands were quick, her voice was clear,
She faced each season without fear.
The seasons turned, the fruit would fall,
Yet love and hope adorned her hall.
She wove her days from sun and rain:
A joyful heart would never wane.

A farmer’s wife, both young and gay,
Could make the darkest sky seem May.
Her song would rise on wings of light,
Chasing away the chill of night.
She gathered eggs and dreams anew,
Beneath the clouds, beneath the blue.
Her laughter blessed the bending wheat,
Life blooming gently at her feet.
She stitched her love through every year—
A tapestry of hope and cheer.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
Within the silent shadows of the night,
When weary hearts have trembled in their grief,
A gentle haven glows with steady light:
God is the refuge, bringing sweet relief.

Beyond the tumult and the swirling storm,
His promise cradles all the soul’s laments;
In sheltering love so tender and so warm,
God is the refuge of his faithful saints.

Though worldly tempests lash and doubts assail,
His presence calms the thunder in our veins;
Within His grace, no evil can prevail—
God is the refuge of his saints.

In storms that howl, when shadows press,
A quiet strength, the soul’s caress—
God is the refuge of his saints:
A fortress when all courage faints.

Through valley deep or mountain high,
His shelter stands, His arms are nigh.
His faithfulness the anchor sure—
His saints in Him will well endure.

So rest, ye weary, bearers of light:
Beyond all darkness glimmers bright
The promise kept, the hope so faint—
God is the refuge of His saints.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Their fortress in the blinding rain,
His love, a balm for every pain—
Their cries, he gathers not in vain.

Under trembling boughs, they rest,
Mid empty fear and faithless jest.
From silent lips to open skies,
He listens still, and spirit flies.

O children shod in hope and awe,
Within the shelter of His law,
Lies peace that storms and sorrow paint—
God is the refuge of his saints.

Upon the jagged edge of care,
When shadows press and hearts despair,
A gentle voice, a harbor waits:
God is the refuge of his saints.

Beneath his wings, the restless cease,
Their burdens traded for his peace.
When storms of night in fury rage,
His love remains, our firmest stage.

So lift your eyes, ye weary souls,
And rest where heavenly comfort rolls,
For in His promise, hope retains:
God is the refuge of his saints.

In silent rooms of longing, hearts confess
Their tender hopes, petitioned in distress.
Yet firm and bright, the promise flowers anew:
God is the refuge of his saints—it's true.

Against the battering winds of doubt and fear,
His sovereign strength remains, a presence near.
From dawn till dusk, in green or desert land,
He gathers saints within His gentle hand.

Thus, clothed in peace that trouble never taints,
They find their shelter: God, the refuge of His saints.

His steady hand is always near;
No promise made He will not keep,
No cry of sorrow fails His ear.
The world may thunder at the gate,
And tempests hammer roof and wall,
But faith endures and conquers fate—
For God is refuge, strong for all.
So gather close, you hopeful hearts,
Within the shelter He has made;
In storm or sun, His love imparts
A light upon your darkest shade.

In quiet sighs and trembling days,
God shelters those who trust His ways;
His saints may wander, hope worn thin,
Yet find their rest and strength within.
When mountains move and valleys quake,
And all the world’s foundations shake,
Still, in His arms no fear remains—
God is the refuge of His saints.
His promises endure the night,
A lamp to guide through fading light;
No storm or sorrow stands too great,
For in His hands, His children wait.
So, faithful hearts, lift up your gaze—
Across the years, through all your days,
He holds you close when trial paints:
God is the refuge of His saints.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
Beneath the shadow of ancient skies,
A haven dwells—unseen by mortal eyes.
God is the refuge of his saints, a wall
Of mercy steadfast, sheltering all
Who stagger weary from the world’s complaints.
Within grace’s fortress, sorrow faints:
Worn hearts find rest, and shrouded fears
Dissolve like mist as morning nears.
In trembling quiet, prayer ascends,
And blessed assurance softly bends
To cradle souls in sacred peace—
Where storms may rage, yet sorrows cease.
O boundless Rock, O gentle flame:
God holds his saints who call His name.

God is the refuge of his saints—
A harbor in the storm’s abyss;
The trembling soul who longs and faints
Finds shelter in his tenderness.

When thunders roll and shadows press,
When hopes are shattered, dreams erased,
He folds his children’s weariness
In arms of mercy, calm, and grace.

No fleeting grief, nor world’s distress,
Can break the promise, pure and true,
Of sanctuary for the blessed—
His presence ever breaking through.

God is the refuge of his saints—
In silent halls where heartache slants,
A sanctuary from the wild,
A whisper, gentle as a child.

Their trembling feet may bleed on stone,
Their voices cry in undertone—
Yet in his shadow, fear departs:
A shield encircling weary hearts.

He leads them through the darkest night,
Bathed in serenity and light,
To rest where troubled spirits cease,
Their guardian, their strength, their peace.

Upon the mountain’s silent brow,
Where winds contest and time allows,
God is the refuge of his saints—
A bastion built not by constraint,
But out of mercy, boundless, deep
Where aching hearts and wanderers weep.
He folds his saints in quiet arms,
Dispels the storm, disarms all harms,
And in the hush that follows rain,
Their faith restored, they rise again.

O hallowed ground, O sacred rest,
In refuge, souls are truly blessed.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A gentle shield from fear’s constraint;
Beneath His wings the hurried rest,
Their hurried pulses soothed and blessed.

In hardship’s fire, in sorrow’s deep,
His promises the faithful keep.
Who trust in Him lack not for light—
He guides their footfalls through the night.

Amid life’s storms, His love endures;
His steadfast peace and hope ensures.
Each burdened heart, in Him, can know:
God guards His saints—He loves them so.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself within the linen dusk,
Where shadows slip inside her quiet pride
And hopes fade gentle, silent, and unbrushed.

A hush becomes her armor; she retreats
Behind the velvet boundaries of her mind,
Letting the world’s harsh cadence lose its beat—
Here solitude and hexed comfort intertwine.

When stars arrange themselves with secret codes,
She wonders, softly, if she’s understood,
Or if the ache of wishing she was bodes
A sweet surrender to the secret wood.

Sometimes she wants only to disappear—
A whisper folded, lingering, unclear.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip between the cracks of ordinary time,
A shadow lessoned in the rhythm of retreat,
Hands quiet at her sides, forgetting songs to mime.

Her hopes are paper boats on swollen streams,
Pages closed against the sudden storm.
She welcomes hush, a cloak of cloudy dreams,
And weaves the night where yearning keeps her warm.

Unable to speak the ache outside,
She listens to her heartbeat in the gloom—
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And grow unnoticed in her silent room.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Burrowing deep beneath her battered skin,
She weaves a nest of silence, tucked inside
Where outer voices fade and thoughts begin.

A softer world constructed, dim and kind—
Warmed by the hush that curtains troubled skies.
The light outside grows distant, undefined,
While comfort pools beneath her cautious eyes.

Yet in the hollow breath of sheltered space,
She finds herself anew, both lost and found,
And gathers courage, tender as her grace,
To step—when ready—back upon the ground.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Under the gentle press of dusk’s old shawl.
The world too loud, emotions battered wide—
Her solace comes in shadows on the wall.

She lets her laughter dwindle into hush,
Pretends she’s branches rustling far away.
In solitude, she feels her spirit flush,
Welcomes the hush of dreams that softly sway.

Tomorrow, she may greet the glaring dawn,
But now, she lies invisible, withdrawn.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide—
To pull the world’s drapery over her eyes,
Chasing silence that makes the starlight slide
Through the cracks of her handcrafted disguise.

She sinks, unmoored, behind the silver screen
Of eyelids bathed in twilight’s weary hue.
There, secrets soften, edges turn serene,
And wounds can breathe in safety, cool and blue.

Perhaps tomorrow she’ll return unbowed,
But tonight she tucks herself behind the shrouds.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:

And silence weaves a safe and tender space.

Deep in the folded pocket of her mind,
She tucks her worries, buries yesterday.
Under soft covers, comfort’s arms unwind,
And all the noisy world is kept at bay.

Yet morning gently pulls her from retreat—
Kind sunlight on her brow, a hopeful sign.
Renewed, she greets the waking city’s beat,
The hidden strength within her quietly shines.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Enfolded in a shadow’s gentle palm,
To cast her weary thoughts like leaves aside
And float inside a breathless, silent calm.

Not lost, but resting far from blinding gaze—
Invisible as starlight in the dawn,
She lets the world spin past, a blurry haze,
Until she finds the will to carry on.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Retreat within the shell that keeps her whole.
Let windows close and doors swing softly wide,
To shield the fragile weather of her soul.

In corners where the burdens slip away,
She nurtures small, slow-growing seeds of peace,
And in that stillness finds, for one brief day,
Her eager longing for escape can cease.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the hush of blankets, dusk, and dreams.
Away from muted echoes that reside
In busy halls and sunlit morning beams.

She listens to the wild, unspoken song
Of hidden places only she can know,
And finds among the quiet where she belongs
A secret garden where her heart can grow.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Folded small within a sea of sighs,
Invisible as mist before a tide,
Erased beneath the sweep of midnight skies.

She’s not running, only softly gone
To where her spirit gathers strength again,
Birthing fresh tomorrows from the dawn,
Returning fiercer than she once had been.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Behind the curtains of her quiet room;

For gentle petals yet to fully bloom.
She curls into a cocoon of thought,
Invisible, serene, alone and still.
Outside, a war of questions she's not fought—
Inside, she finds a peace the world can't kill.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Letting the rain blur footprints on the path;
A sigh pressed softly to the pane outside,
Escaping worries like the morning's wrath.
She gathers comfort in the gentle shade,
A whispered sanctuary for her heart.
There, with her solitude, she is unafraid—
Each breath a tender moment set apart.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Retreating from noise in the hush of night;
She draws the stars around her, side by side,
A softer cloak than the sun’s hard light.
Beneath her blanket, she builds a fort,
Walls of stories, drifting thought,
Not lost, but resting, safe in port,

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

Between the spaces cracks and shadows slide,
And whispered wishes nestle gently there.
It isn't fear that keeps her from the view—
Just the longing for a world that's still,
Where moments linger, soft and few,
And she can dream as much as she will.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
Streetlights flicker soft benedictions above our clasped hands—
Neon spills like stained glass on rain-soaked pavement,
Lost in the hush between hurried taxis and laughter.
Your shadow lingers on windowpanes of café light,
My heart echoing footsteps that mirror your own.
Above us, towers write their longing in silver alphabets,
As night folds possibility in every unspoken mile.
And when, in the city in which I love you,
I find home not in walls, but wherever we breathe the same dusk air.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The river's voice murmurs under arched bridges,
Light pools in alleyways where strangers pass,
I carry your gaze, a lantern through midnight crowds.
Lost among stories brick-etched and lamplight-warmed,
We are two sighs threading narrow cobblestone dreams.
Here, distance is measured in silence and starlight,
And the city inhales us, names us as its own.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Under scaffolding and sycamores, I find your laughter,
Spilling from stoop to gutter, filling the gaps between horns.
The buses moan, pigeons scatter like thoughts,
Yet our shadows cling to each other in neon halos.
Even the sirens, echoing off glass, sound like longing.
And when I look up—between you, me, and skyline—
I see our hopes blinking, infinite in windowed light.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Dawn paints its blush across faceless high-rises,
We walk unnamed streets with cherished anonymity.
Your hand in mine becomes an anchor in this restless sea,
As coffee-scented breezes swirl around market stalls.
Beneath blinking marquees, we are both lost and found,
Mapping the tender geography of a thousand glances.
And so, in this city, I love you again—
Where every moment is stitched into something belonging.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Glass towers shimmer with our shared memory,
Each avenue hums with the pulse of your voice.
Beneath braiding streetcars and blooming dusk,
I find fragments of sunlight caught in your smile.
This metropolis of longing weaves us into maps unseen,
And even as crowds swirl, time hushes—
For in this city, loving you feels endless,
A promise stitched in every corner where we meet.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text:
And when, in the city in which I love you,  
Dusk finds us threading through lamplit streets,  
The world hums on beyond the glass and dew,  
While shadows curl like secrets at our feet.  
Breakfast cafés waver in dawn’s blush;  
Sirens echo stories old and new;  
Above, the stars hush dreams into a hush  
Just for this city in which I love you.  
Hold my hand, let bridges span the blue—  
Every stranger’s face a poem I read.  
The city writes us, bold and fleeting too,  
On peppered air and on the silent need.

And when, in the city in which I love you,  
Brick and glass blink awake to a rising sun,  
I wander your boulevards, hoping my heart  
Will learn something new about longing.  
Taxi lights flicker studies of patience.  
Someone dances alone by a window.  
Shadowed alleys cradle the echo of laughter—  
There is tenderness in how the night remembers.  
And if ever our paths cross in the fog,  
Let it be with gentleness;  
This city, this feeling, this hope  
Thrives because you walk somewhere within it,  
An unseen gravity tugging all my compass needles north.

And when, in the city in which I love you,  
Neon drizzles down rain-slicked streets,  
I gather the fragments of your voice  
From the echoing chambers of midnight trains.  
My longing spills across cracked sidewalks,  
Past windows blurred with golden intent,  
Where laughter rises like smoke  
And yearning drifts beneath the painted lights.  
In this city, I keep loving you—  
Bravely, in the hush of strangers' footsteps,  
Softly, as the river curls through stone,  
Hopeful, as twilight rinses sorrow  
In the city that keeps your secret and mine.

And when, in the city in which I love you,  
Every street corner cradles your memory.  
Pigeons take wing over market stalls—  
Their beating feathers, a private semaphore.  
Morning spills gold on steps we once counted,  
And laughter clings to café chairs.  
Each passing hour reshapes your outline—  
A wisp of perfume, dusk on your shoulder,  
The hush after fortune tellers fold up for night.  
In this city, I learn patience by heart—  
Measure my longing in crosswalks and stoplights,  
Wait for your echo in subway tunnels,  
Tentatively whole, in the city in which I love you.

And when, in the city in which I love you,  
Time dilates in the hush between passing trains.  
Your laughter floats down cobblestone alleys,  
Brushed by the midnight hush of bicycles and rain.  
I have traced your outline in the city’s silhouette,  
Found your smile in streetlamps and carousels.  
Beneath graffiti and ancient brick, hope lingers,  
Whispering stories only we remember.  
The city breathes slow as I wait for dawn—  
Feet aching but heart awake,  
Turning a corner, I meet your absence, waving,  
And carry it gently through glittering dawn.

in this city where loving you feels new.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

responses.text:
A poet loses his power for poetry—
Once words had wings of monarchs, bold and bright,
Now, silence pools in ink abandoned, free—
A paper’s dawn, but no sun, no light.

His pen lies idle, grasped in longing hands,
Thoughts, scattered ashes, drift in empty air.
Once he commanded seas and distant lands,

Yet in soft hush of powerless despair,

The unwritten poem, waiting to break through.

Words clamor at the threshold but do not pass,
The mind a winter garden, frost on every leaf,
Ideas brittle as icicles, silence thick as glass.

Once rivers of language surged beneath the skin,
Now tides withdraw, leaving shorelines bare.
Metaphors wither before they can begin,
And the world, unadorned, is blunt and unaware.

Yet in barren hours a subtle hope may start:
A green shoot breaking stone, a soundless spark—
For loss and longing, too, are forms of art,
And silent poets wait for the returning dark.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
His tongue, once a silver current,
Now stumbles on stone, starved for sound.
Dreams, once purple and sea-wild, turn gray.

He listens for thunder. The sky aches, empty.
Ink bottles gather dusk in trembling glass.
Fingers forget the shape of longing,
And every word dissolves before it’s found.

But deep beneath silence, possible worlds
Curl like undiscovered seeds in winter—
A power lost may only be a power sleeping,
And in one hushed heartbeat, perhaps: return.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
The muse’s laughter slips out the window,
Words fracture in the throat before they land,
The world’s wild song fades to common prose.

He waits for inspiration’s gentle tap,
The familiar flame now just a memory,
Empty pages gather the dust of hope,
While longing dances in unreachable harmony.

Yet in the betweenness of silence and regret,
He discovers the shape of loss, carves its borders, 
And finds that surrender, too, can be beauty—
A poem unsaid but woven between borders.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
What once brimmed like rivers now trickles like rain,
Verse deserts him, his quill a dry branch,
Stanzas evaporate, half-made, in his brain.

He follows old trails where language once bloomed,
Finds them barren, the colors bled out,
His voice echoes thin in the hollows of rooms
Where metaphors silence him, heavy with doubt.

Yet absence, too, has a kind of grace:
In the void, new forms and meanings wait,
So let the poet wander, lost, erased—
Sometimes the blank page is only fate.

Limitless, aching, his heart asks why.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
Sharp silver quill now trembling in weak hands,
Ink that once flowed in rivers, stutters dry,
Dreams once crystalline cloud in drifting sands.

He watches silent alphabets dissolve,
Tethers untwined between heart and tongue,
Longing for one fragile syllable resolved,
A melody only memory has sung.

Yet somewhere in the silence, seeds remain,
Hidden promises, stubborn, beneath the pain.

A poet loses his power for poetry—a silence grows behind his lips.
He combs the air for once-bright words, iron heavy, out of reach.
The universe retreats to grayscale, where color was only ever speech.

He builds small towers out of longing, resting weary in the hush.
But in the marrow of his muteness, a thousand lines remember him still.

Perhaps the next rain, or a sparrow’s wing, will bring them home again.

A poet loses his power for poetry—
His metered breath, now ragged air,
The metaphors he used to see—
Lost in the marrow of despair.

He grapples with unspoken night,
Where ink and longing fail to meet;
Yet, sometimes in this silent plight,
A different beauty—strange, discreet—
Emerges from the waning light, complete.

A poet loses his power for poetry,
And suddenly the world is turned opaque;
What once was music caught in every tree
Is now the hush a heart can barely take.

He gathers phrases by the fading light,
But all dissolve before they reach the page;
In silent rooms he learns a new, vast night,
Time’s hush, unwritten wisdom, age to age.

And yet, perhaps, from losing song,
A deeper song is born all along.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'There is a law which guarantees'

responses.text:
There is a law which guarantees
That sun and shadow swirl and cease:
The seasons turn, the rivers bend,
Time rewrites what we pretend.

There is a force in branch and seed,
Assuring life in word and deed.
No rule is written in firm stone—
Change is the law we all have known.

So worry not for what may flee:
There is a law which guarantees
Each ending births a start anew—
For this, dear friend, your heart may strew.

There is a law which guarantees
That hearts will break and sometimes heal.
That every wave returns to seas,
And wounds aright, if given zeal.

The branches crack, but roots remain,
In hidden earth, outlasting pain.
There is a law, both soft and sure,
That love survives, and wounds mature.

There is a law which guarantees
The rising dawn after dark decrees.
No promise written in human hand,
But woven into the silent land.

Hope glints in the dew-bright grass,
Life persists: a stubborn class.
What you plant, the law will raise—
Unseen, but constant, through all our days.

There is a law which guarantees
That every echo finds release—
From shouts across a valley wild
To whispered dreams of every child.

In gravity, in gentle rain,
In laughter lingering after pain,
This law runs deep, unseen but true:
What you send forth returns to you.

There is a law which guarantees
That starlight journeys through the freeze—
A truth that hums in silent skies,
Unwavering as morning’s rise.

It governs every breath and leap,
In what we sow and what we reap.
Some call it fate, or hope, or chance;
A quiet thread in life's expanse.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'There is a law which guarantees'

There is a law which guarantees—

There is a law which guarantees

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

responses.text:
Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
Life’s mantra whispered under breath—
Dawns bloom with promise we struggle to keep,
Routine’s rhythm, the pause before rest.

In the morning chill, hopes quietly leap,
As sunlight traces familiar lines.
Yet, as hours march and day grows deep,
We’re carried by clocks and their chimes.

But between these patterned steps of time,
Subtle joys in the mundane reside—
A fleeting smile, a silent rhyme,
A dream that quietly bides.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep,
And through it all, we sow and reap.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
The pendulum swings, no time to weep.
A cycle turning, day after day,
Monotony’s comfort holds us in sway.

But beneath routine’s silent sweep,
Reside quiet moments ours to keep:
A coffee’s warmth, a window’s gleam,
Tiny embers feeding a dream.

So let us find in daily round
A subtle joy, a gentle sound,
For even in patterned, worn-out feet,
There’s poetry where cycles meet.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep —
Like a well-worn path in dew.
Tumble from soft sheets to clockwork days,
Chasing meaning in the things we do.

Under fluorescent hum, our hours creep—
A hurried lunch, a patient sigh.
Yet laughter seeps through the office walls,
A sunbeam in the weary eye.

Returning each night to familiar light,
We savor quiet at the close,
A gentle touch, a silent hope,
And stories told before we doze.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
The lines we live, the roads we keep,
Threads of hours, tightly spun,
Spinning circles, one by one.

Yet in the haze between the lines,
A wild idea softly shines:
A painted sky, a whispered tune,
A wish upon the afternoon.

So let us dream amid the grind,
And in this rhythm, meaning find.

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—
The silent prayer the morning speaks,
Machines and faces, hum and sweep,
The city’s rhythm never weak.

In evening’s hush we quietly reap
The comfort that our bodies seek;
Light dims, the crickets start to peep,
Tomorrow’s echo in dreams’ deep creek.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Wake, work, home, eat sleep'

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep,

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—

Echoed footsteps in the hall,

Breakfast crumbs and subway steam,

But in the quiet after all,

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—

Wake, work, home, eat, sleep—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'That's my window. This minute'

responses.text:
That's my window. This minute,
A trembling square of quiet blue,
The world beyond grows almost infinite
While shadows stitch a gentle view.
I sit, hands folded, breathing slow,
Counting the things I almost know:
How time, in shafts of embered gold,
Spills secrets new and secrets old.
So much can shift, in this hush—
A racing cloud, a sparrow's rush,
Petals drifting past the sill—
And here I am, soft and still.
That's my window. This minute—mine—
A quiet pulse outside of time.

That's my window. This minute
Light blooms on its edge, fleeting—a wisp.
A hush between rain and sun,
The rim of the moment pressed like a kiss.
An old bird glances through the glass,
Shadows paint the corners thin.
I am both watcher and the watched,
Caught in the trembling between.
For time tastes cold on the windowpane,
Every second an ache, a hush.
Yet I claim it—here and now—
My window, my minute, my hush.

That's my window. This minute, the street below runs thick with yellows—cars, laughter, wind.
Rain scribbles patterns I’ll forget in an hour:
Old regrets dribble from the eaves; fresh hope crackles in sudden sun.
A child passes, umbrella spinning, a tiny wheel in the universe,
And I am tethered to glass, present, aware,
Owning the patchwork view stitched, torn, renewed
In the hush between this tick and the next.
My window: small, familiar, vast as longing.
This minute: fleeting, bright, mine.

That's my window. This minute
frames a story nobody wrote—
golden-leaved, the elm leans in,
rain-freckled, trembling with hope.
Inside, tea steams, clock hands tick;
the world hushes on the sill—
every glimmer, drought, and trickle
held briefly, brilliantly, still.
Will I claim tomorrow, or yesterday?
Only the pane knows how to begin it:
I rest in the light that happens here,
my window. This minute.

That's my window. This minute
catches morning humming low,
as new rain etches silver lines
that only I will know.
A pigeon balances on stone,
dreams flicker in the glass—
my heart tracks every cloud that passes,
hoping this, too, shall pass.
I hold the hush, the hush holds me—
at my window, in this minute,
while the world turns restlessly
towards everything within it.

Where there is a need,
